questions.question: With respect to the certification of airmen, which are categories of aircraft?
answers: Gyroplane, helicopter, airship, free balloon.
Airplane, rotorcraft, glider, lighter-than-air.
Single-engine land and sea, multiengine land and sea.
questions.explanation: Category of aircraft, as used with respect to the certification, ratings, privileges, and limitations of airmen, means a broad classification of aircraft. Examples include airplane, rotorcraft, glider, and lighter-than-air. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: With respect to the certification of airmen, which is a class of aircraft?
answers: Airplane, rotorcraft, glider, lighter-than-air.
Single-engine land and sea, multiengine land and sea.
Lighter-than-air, airship, hot air balloon, gas balloon.
questions.explanation: Class of aircraft, as used with respect to the certification, ratings, privileges, and limitations of airmen, means a classification of aircraft within a category having similar operating characteristics. Examples include single engine, multiengine, land, water, gyroplane, helicopter, airship, and free balloon. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: The definition of nighttime is
answers: sunset to sunrise.
1 hour after sunset to 1 hour before sunrise.
the time between the end of evening civil twilight and the beginning of morning civil twilight.
questions.explanation: "Night" means the time between the end of evening civil twilight and the beginning of morning civil twilight (as published in The Air Almanac) converted to local time. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: With respect to the certification of aircraft, which is a category of aircraft?
answers: Normal, utility, acrobatic.
Airplane, rotorcraft, glider.
Landplane, seaplane.
questions.explanation: Category of aircraft, as used with respect to the certification of aircraft, means a grouping of aircraft based upon intended use or operating limitations. Examples include transport, normal, utility, acrobatic, limited, restricted, and provisional. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: With respect to the certification of aircraft, which is a class of aircraft?
answers: Airplane, rotorcraft, glider, balloon.
Normal, utility, acrobatic, limited.
Transport, restricted, provisional.
questions.explanation: Class of aircraft, as used with respect to the certification of aircraft, means a broad grouping of aircraft having similar characteristics of propulsion, flight, or landing. Examples include airplane, rotorcraft, glider, balloon, landplane, and seaplane. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: An ATC clearance provides
answers: priority over all other traffic.
adequate separation from all traffic.
authorization to proceed under specified traffic conditions in controlled airspace.
questions.explanation: A clearance issued by ATC is predicated on known traffic and known physical airport conditions. An ATC clearance means an authorization by ATC, for the purpose of preventing collision between known airplanes, for an airplane to proceed under specified conditions within controlled airspace. (14 CFR 1.1)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: Which V-speed represents maximum flap extended speed?
answers: VFE.
VLOF.
VFC.
questions.explanation: VFE means the maximum flap extended speed. (14 CFR 1.2)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: Which V-speed represents maximum landing gear extended speed?
answers: VLE.
VLO.
VFE.
questions.explanation: VLE means the maximum landing gear extended speed. (14 CFR 1.2)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: VNO is defined as the
answers: normal operating range.
never-exceed speed.
maximum structural cruising speed.
questions.explanation: VNO is defined as the maximum structural cruising speed. (14 CFR 1.2)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: Which V-speed represents maneuvering speed?
answers: VA.
VLO.
VNE.
questions.explanation: VA means design maneuvering speed. (14 CFR 1.2)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: Which would provide the greatest gain in altitude in the shortest distance during climb after takeoff?
answers: VY.
VA.
VX.
questions.explanation: VX means the best angle of climb airspeed (i.e., the airspeed which will provide the greatest gain in altitude in the shortest distance). (14 CFR 1.2 and FAA-H-8083-3C Chap 3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: VS0 is defined as the
answers: stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration.
stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in a specified configuration.
stalling speed or minimum takeoff safety speed.
questions.explanation: VS0 is defined as the stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration. (14 CFR 1.2)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: After takeoff, which airspeed would the pilot use to gain the most altitude in a given period of time?
answers: VY.
VX.
VA.
questions.explanation: VY means the airspeed for the best rate of climb (i.e., the airspeed that you use to gain the most altitude in a given period of time). (14 CFR 1.2 and FAA-H-8083-3C Chap 3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 1: Definitions and Abbreviations

questions.question: How long does the Airworthiness Certificate of an aircraft remain valid?
answers: As long as the aircraft has a current Registration Certificate.
Indefinitely, unless the aircraft suffers major damage.
As long as the aircraft is maintained and operated as required by Federal Aviation Regulations.
questions.explanation: The airworthiness certificate of an airplane remains valid as long as the airplane is in an airworthy condition, i.e., operated and maintained as required by Federal Aviation Regulations. (14 CFR 21.181)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 21: Certification Procedures for Products and Articles

questions.question: What should an owner or operator know about Airworthiness Directives (ADs)?
answers: For informational purposes only.
They are mandatory.
They are voluntary.
questions.explanation: ADs are issued under 14 CFR Part 39 by the FAA to require correction of unsafe conditions found in an airplane, an airplane engine, a propeller, or an appliance when such conditions exist and are likely to exist or develop in other products of the same design. Since ADs are issued under 14 CFR Part 39, they are regulatory and must be complied with, unless a specific exemption is granted. (14 CFR 39.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 39: Airworthiness Directives

questions.question: May a pilot operate an aircraft that is not in compliance with an Airworthiness Directive (AD)?
answers: Yes, under VFR conditions only.
Yes, ADs are only voluntary.
Yes, if allowed by the AD.
questions.explanation: An AD is used to notify aircraft owners and other interested persons of unsafe conditions and prescribe the conditions under which the product (e.g., an aircraft) may continue to be operated. An AD may be one of an emergency nature requiring immediate compliance upon receipt or one of a less urgent nature requiring compliance within a relatively longer period of time. You may operate an airplane that is not in compliance with an AD, if such operation is allowed by the AD. (14 CFR Part 39)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 39: Airworthiness Directives

questions.question: What regulation allows a private pilot to perform preventive maintenance?
questions.explanation: Preventive maintenance means simple or minor preservation operations and the replacement of small standard parts not involving complex assembly operations. Appendix A to Part 43 provides a list of work that is considered preventive maintenance. Part 43 allows a person who holds a pilot certificate to perform preventive maintenance on any aircraft owned or operated by that pilot that is not used in air carrier service. (14 CFR 43.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: Who may perform preventive maintenance on an aircraft and approve it for return to service?
answers: Student or Recreational pilot.
Private or Commercial pilot.
None of the answers are correct.
questions.explanation: A person who holds a pilot certificate issued under Part 61 may perform preventive maintenance on any airplane owned or operated by that pilot that is not used in air carrier service. To approve the airplane for return to service after preventive maintenance is performed by a pilot, the pilot must hold at least a private pilot certificate. (14 CFR 43.7)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: When preventive maintenance is performed on an aircraft, what paperwork is required?
answers: A full, detailed description of the work done must be entered in the airframe logbook.
The date the work was completed, and the name of the person who did the work must be entered in the airframe and engine logbook.
The signature, certificate number, and kind of certificate held by the person approving the work, and a description of the work must be entered in the aircraft maintenance records.
questions.explanation: After preventive maintenance has been performed, the signature, certificate number, and kind of certificate held by the person approving the work and a description of the work must be entered in the aircraft maintenance records. (14 CFR 43.9)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: What documentation is required when a pilot has performed preventive maintenance on an aircraft?
answers: Pilot performed maintenance does not need to be documented.
Only major repairs and alterations need to be documented.
The pilot is to make an entry in the aircraft's maintenance records.
questions.explanation: A pilot who performs preventive maintenance must make an entry in the maintenance record containing the pilot's signature, certificate number, kind of certificate held, date of completion, and a description of the work performed. (14 CFR 43.9)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: Which operation would be described as preventive maintenance?
answers: Servicing landing gear wheel bearings.
Alteration of main seat support brackets.
Engine adjustments to allow automotive gas to be used.
questions.explanation: Appendix A to Part 43 provides a list of work that is considered preventive maintenance. Preventive maintenance means simple or minor preservation operations and the replacement of small standard parts not involving complex assembly operations. Servicing landing gear wheel bearings, such as cleaning and greasing, is considered preventive maintenance. (14 CFR Part 43 App A)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: Which operation would be described as preventive maintenance?
answers: Repair of landing gear brace struts.
Replenishing hydraulic fluid.
Repair of portions of skin sheets by making additional seams.
questions.explanation: Appendix A to Part 43 provides a list of work that is considered preventive maintenance. Preventive maintenance means simple or minor preservation operations and the replacement of small standard parts not involving complex assembly operations. An example of preventive maintenance is replenishing hydraulic fluid. (14 CFR Part 43 App A)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 43: Maintenance, Preventive Maintenance, Rebuilding, and Alteration

questions.question: Is it legal to fly on the dealer's registration after a buyer purchased an airplane from that dealer?
answers: Yes, the airplane can be flown by the buyer for 30 days.
No, the airplane cannot be flown by the buyer and has to be registered.
Yes, the airplane can be flown by the buyer for 120 days.
questions.explanation: A Dealer's Aircraft Registration Certificate is another form of registration. It is valid only for flights within the United States by the manufacturer or a dealer for flight testing or demonstration for sale and must be removed by the dealer when the aircraft is sold. The back side of the registration is filled out with the appropriate information from the sale as well as the new owner's name. The certificate must then be mailed back to the FAA registry in Oklahoma City. Doing so protects the buyer and seller. This requirement is law under 14 CFR 47.41(b), which became effective March 31, 2008. (14 CFR Part 47)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 47: Aircraft Registration

questions.question: When must a current pilot certificate be in the pilot's personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft?
answers: When acting as a crew chief during launch and recovery.
Only when passengers are carried.
Any time when acting as pilot in command or as a required crewmember.
questions.explanation: Current and appropriate pilot and medical certificates must be in your personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft when you act as pilot in command (PIC) or as a required pilot flight crewmember. (14 CFR 61.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: A recreational or private pilot acting as pilot in command, or in any other capacity as a required pilot flight crewmember, must have in his or her personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft a current
answers: logbook endorsement to show that a flight review has been satisfactorily accomplished.
medical certificate if required and an appropriate pilot certificate.
endorsement on the pilot certificate to show that a flight review has been satisfactorily accomplished.
questions.explanation: Current and appropriate pilot and medical certificates must be in your personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft when you act as pilot in command (PIC) or as a required pilot flight crewmember. (14 CFR 61.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: What document(s) must be in your personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft while operating as pilot in command of an aircraft?
answers: Certificates showing accomplishment of a checkout in the aircraft and a current satisfactory flight review.
A pilot certificate with an endorsement showing accomplishment of an annual flight review and a pilot logbook showing recency of experience.
An appropriate pilot certificate and an appropriate current medical certificate if required.
questions.explanation: Current and appropriate pilot and medical certificates must be in your personal possession or readily accessible in the aircraft when you act as pilot in command (PIC) or as a required pilot flight crewmember. (14 CFR 61.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: Each person who holds a pilot certificate or a medical certificate shall present it for inspection upon the request of any
answers: authorized representative of the Department of Transportation.
person in a position of authority.
local law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: Each person who holds a pilot certificate, flight instructor certificate, medical certificate, authorization, or license required by Federal Aviation Regulations shall present it for inspection upon the request of the Administrator of the FAA, an authorized representative of the National Transportation Safety Board, or any federal, state, or local law enforcement officer. (14 CFR 61.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: How soon after the conviction for driving while intoxicated by alcohol or drugs shall it be reported to the FAA's Security and Hazardous Materials Safety Office?
answers: No later than 60 days after the motor vehicle action.
No later than 30 working days after the motor vehicle action.
Required to be reported upon renewal of medical certificate.
questions.explanation: Each person holding a certificate under Part 61 shall provide a written report of each motor vehicle action involving alcohol or drugs to the FAA's Security and Hazardous Materials Safety Office no later than 60 days after the motor vehicle action. (14 CFR 61.15)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: How soon after the conviction for driving while intoxicated by alcohol or drugs shall it be reported to the FAA, and which department should this be reported to?
answers: Within 60 days to the Airmen Certification Branch.
Within 60 days to the Security and Hazardous Materials Safety Office.
Within 60 days to the Regulatory Support Division.
questions.explanation: Each person holding a certificate under Part 61 shall provide a written report of each motor vehicle action involving alcohol or drugs to the FAA's Security and Hazardous Materials Safety Office no later than 60 days after the motor vehicle action. (14 CFR 61.15)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: A Third-Class Medical Certificate is issued to a 36-year-old pilot on August 10, this year. To exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot Certificate, the medical certificate will be valid until midnight on
answers: August 10, 3 years later.
August 31, 5 years later.
August 31, 3 years later.
questions.explanation: A pilot may exercise the privileges of a private pilot certificate under a third-class medical certificate until it expires at the end of the last day of the month 5 years after it was issued, for pilots less than 40 years old on the date of the medical examination. A third-class medical certificate issued to a 36-year-old pilot on Aug. 10 will be valid until midnight on Aug. 31, 5 years later. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: A Third-Class Medical Certificate is issued to a 51-year-old pilot on May 3, this year. To exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot Certificate, the medical certificate will be valid until midnight on
answers: May 3, 1 year later.
May 31, 1 year later.
May 31, 2 years later.
questions.explanation: A pilot may exercise the privileges of a private pilot certificate under a third-class medical certificate until it expires at the end of the last day of the month 2 years after it was issued, for pilots 40 years old or older on the date of the medical examination. A third-class medical certificate issued to a 51-year-old pilot on May 3 will be valid until midnight on May 31, 2 years later. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: For private pilot operations, a Second-Class Medical Certificate issued to a 42-year-old pilot on July 15, this year, will expire at midnight on
answers: July 15, 2 years later.
July 31, 1 year later.
July 31, 2 years later.
questions.explanation: For private pilot operations, a second-class medical certificate will expire at the end of the last day of the month, 2 years after it was issued, for pilots 40 years old or older on the date of the medical examination. For private pilot operations, a second-class medical certificate issued to a 42-year-old pilot on July 15 will be valid until midnight on July 31, 2 years later. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: A Third-Class Medical Certificate was issued to a 19-year-old pilot on August 10, this year. To exercise the privileges of a recreational or private pilot certificate, the medical certificate will expire at midnight on
answers: August 10, 2 years later.
August 31, 5 years later.
August 31, 2 years later.
questions.explanation: A pilot may exercise the privileges of a recreational or private pilot certificate under a third-class medical certificate until it expires at the end of the last day of the month 5 years after it was issued, for pilots less than 40 years old at the time of the medical examination. A third-class medical certificate issued to a 19-year-old pilot on Aug. 10 will be valid until midnight on Aug. 31, 5 years later. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: For private pilot operations, a First-Class Medical Certificate issued to a 23-year-old pilot on October 21, this year, will expire at midnight on
answers: October 21, 2 years later.
October 31, next year.
October 31, 5 years later.
questions.explanation: For private pilot operations, a first-class medical certificate will expire at the end of the last day of the 60th calendar month (5 years) after the month of the date of examination shown on the medical certificate for pilots less than 40 years old on the date of the medical examination. Thus, a first-class medical certificate issued to a 23-year-old pilot on October 21 will be valid until midnight on October 31, 60 calendar months (5 years) after the month of the date of examination. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: In order to qualify for BasicMed, you must have received a comprehensive examination from
answers: An FAA-designated Aviation Medical Examiner within the previous 60 months.
A state-licensed physician within the previous 24 months.
A state-licensed physician within the previous 48 months.
questions.explanation: In order to qualify for BasicMed, you must have received a comprehensive examination from a state-licensed physician within the previous 48 months. (14 CFR 61.23)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: Before a person holding a private pilot certificate may act as pilot in command of a high-performance airplane, that person must have
answers: passed a flight test in that airplane from an FAA inspector.
an endorsement in that person's logbook that he or she is competent to act as pilot in command.
received ground and flight instruction from an authorized flight instructor who then endorses that person's logbook.
questions.explanation: A private pilot may not act as pilot in command of a high-performance airplane (an airplane with an engine of more than 200 horsepower) unless they have received and logged ground and flight training from an authorized instructor who has certified in his or her logbook that they are proficient to operate a high-performance airplane. (14 CFR 61.31)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: In order to act as pilot in command of a high-performance airplane, a pilot must have
answers: made and logged three solo takeoffs and landings in a high-performance airplane.
received and logged ground and flight instruction in an airplane that has more than 200 horsepower.
passed a flight test in a high-performance airplane.
questions.explanation: Prior to acting as pilot in command of an airplane with an engine of more than 200 horsepower, a person is required to receive and log ground and flight training in such an airplane from an authorized flight instructor who has certified in the pilot's logbook that the individual is proficient to operate a high-performance airplane. (14 CFR 61.31)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: What is the definition of a high-performance airplane?
answers: An airplane with 180 horsepower, or retractable landing gear, flaps, and a fixed-pitch propeller.
An airplane with a normal cruise speed in excess of 200 knots.
An airplane with an engine of more than 200 horsepower.
questions.explanation: A high-performance airplane is defined as an airplane with an engine of more than 200 horsepower. (14 CFR 61.31)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: The pilot in command is required to hold a type rating in which aircraft?
answers: Aircraft operated under an authorization issued by the Administrator.
Aircraft having a gross weight of more than 12,500 pounds.
Aircraft involved in ferry flights, training flights, or test flights.
questions.explanation: A person may not act as pilot in command of any of the following aircraft unless they hold a type rating for that aircraft: (1) A large aircraft (except lighter-than-air), i.e., over 12,500 pounds gross weight (2) A turbojet-powered airplane (3) Other aircraft specified by the FAA through aircraft type certificate procedures. (14 CFR 61.31)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To act as PIC of a high-performance airplane, which training or experience would meet the additional requirements?
answers: Logged at least 5 hours as SIC in a high-performance or turbine-powered airplane in the last 12 calendar months.
Received and logged ground and flight training in an airplane with retractable landing gear, flaps, and controllable-pitch propeller.
Received and logged ground and flight training in a high-performance airplane and a received a logbook endorsement.
questions.explanation: To act as a PIC of a high-performance aircraft, the pilot must receive and log ground and flight training from an authorized instructor in a high-performance airplane (an aircraft with more than 200 horsepower) or in a flight simulator or training device that is representative of a high-performance airplane. In addition, that pilot must also receive a one-time endorsement in the pilot's logbook from an authorized instructor who certifies the person is proficient to operate a high-performance airplane. (14 CFR 61.31)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If a recreational or private pilot had a flight review on October 30, this year, when is the next flight review required?
answers: October 30, 2 years later.
October 31, next year.
October 31, 2 years later.
questions.explanation: A pilot is required to have a flight review within the preceding 24 calendar months before the month in which the pilot acts as pilot in command. Thus, a pilot who had a flight review on October 30 of this year must have a flight review completed by October 31, 2 years later. (14 CFR 61.56)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: Each recreational or private pilot is required to have a flight review at least once
answers: every 24 calendar months.
every 12 calendar months.
every 6 calendar months.
questions.explanation: Each recreational or private pilot is required to have a flight review once every 24 calendar months in order to act as pilot in command (PIC) of an aircraft. (14 CFR 61.56)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If a recreational or private pilot had a flight review on August 8, this year, when is the next flight review required?
answers: August 8, next year.
August 31, 1 year later.
August 31, 2 years later.
questions.explanation: A pilot is required to have a flight review within the preceding 24 calendar months before the month in which the pilot acts as pilot in command. Thus, a recreational or private pilot who had a flight review on Aug. 8 of this year must have a flight review completed by Aug. 31, 2 years later. (14 CFR 61.56)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers, a pilot must show by logbook endorsement the satisfactory completion of a flight review or completion of a pilot proficiency check within the preceding
answers: 6 calendar months.
12 calendar months.
24 calendar months.
questions.explanation: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft (whether carrying passengers or not), a pilot must show by logbook endorsement the satisfactory completion of a flight review or completion of a pilot proficiency check within the preceding 24 calendar months. (14 CFR 61.56)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers, the pilot must have made at least three takeoffs and three landings in an aircraft of the same category, class, and if a type rating is required, of the same type, within the preceding
answers: 90 days.
12 calendar months.
24 calendar months.
questions.explanation: To act as pilot in command of an airplane with passengers aboard, you must have made at least three takeoffs and three landings (to a full stop if in a tailwheel airplane) in an airplane of the same category, class, and, if a type rating is required, of the same type within the preceding 90 days. Category refers to airplane, rotorcraft, etc.; class refers to single- or multi-engine, land or sea. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If recency of experience requirements for night flight are not met and official sunset is 1830, the latest time passengers may be carried is
questions.explanation: For the purpose of night recency experience flight time, night is defined as the period beginning 1 hr. after sunset and ending 1 hr. before sunrise. If you have not met the night experience requirements and official sunset is 1830, a landing must be accomplished at or before 1929 if passengers are carried. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers, the pilot must have made three takeoffs and three landings within the preceding 90 days in an aircraft of the same
answers: make and model.
category and class, but not type.
category, class, and type, if a type rating is required.
questions.explanation: No one may act as pilot in command of an airplane carrying passengers unless within the preceding 90 days they have made three takeoffs and three landings as sole manipulator of the controls in an aircraft of the same category and class and, if a type rating is required, the same type. If the aircraft is a tailwheel airplane, the landings must have been to a full stop. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: The three takeoffs and landings that are required to act as pilot in command at night must be done during the time period from
answers: sunset to sunrise.
1 hour after sunset to 1 hour before sunrise.
the end of evening civil twilight to the beginning of morning civil twilight.
questions.explanation: No one may act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers at night (i.e., the period from 1 hour after sunset to 1 hour before sunrise as published in the American Air Almanac) unless they have made three takeoffs and three landings to a full stop within the preceding 90 days, at night, in the category and class of aircraft to be used. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To meet the recency of experience requirements to act as pilot in command carrying passengers at night, a pilot must have made at least three takeoffs and three landings to a full stop within the preceding 90 days in
answers: the same category and class of aircraft to be used.
the same type of aircraft to be used.
any aircraft.
questions.explanation: No one may act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers at night (i.e., the period from 1 hr. after sunset to 1 hr. before sunrise) unless they have made three takeoffs and three landings to a full stop within the preceding 90 days, at night, in the category and class of aircraft to be used. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: The takeoffs and landings required to meet the recency of experience requirements for carrying passengers in a tailwheel airplane
answers: may be touch and go or full stop.
must be touch and go.
must be to a full stop.
questions.explanation: To comply with recency requirements for carrying passengers in a tailwheel airplane, one must have made three takeoffs and landings to a full stop within the past 90 days. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: You have accomplished 25 takeoffs and landings in multi-engine land airplanes in the previous 45 days. For a flight you plan to conduct today, this meets the PIC recency of experience requirements to carry passengers in which airplanes?
answers: Multi- or single-engine land.
Single-engine land airplane.
Multi-engine land airplane.
questions.explanation: No person may act as a pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers unless that person has made at least 3 takeoffs and 3 landings within the preceding 90 days, and the required takeoffs and landings were performed in an aircraft of the same category (airplane, rotorcraft, glider, etc.), class (single-engine, multi-engine, land, water, gyroplane, etc.), and type (if a type rating is required). Therefore, this meets PIC recency of experience requirements to carry passengers in multi-engine land airplanes. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: Your cousin wants you to take him flying. You must have made at least three takeoffs and three landings in your aircraft within the preceding
answers: 90 days.
60 days.
30 days.
questions.explanation: To carry passengers, you must have made three landings and three takeoffs within the preceding 90 days. All three landings must be made in aircraft of the same category, class, and, if a type rating is required, type as the one in which passengers are to be carried. (14 CFR 61.57)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If a certificated pilot changes permanent mailing address and fails to notify the FAA Airmen Certification Branch of the new address, the pilot is entitled to exercise the privileges of the pilot certificate for a period of only
answers: 30 days after the date of the move.
60 days after the date of the move.
90 days after the date of the move.
questions.explanation: If you have changed your permanent mailing address, you may not exercise the privileges of your pilot certificate after 30 days from the date of the address change unless you have notified the FAA in writing of the change. You are required to notify the Airmen Certification Branch at PO Box 25082, Oklahoma City, OK 73125. You may also use the airmen services system on the FAA website. NOTE: While you must notify the FAA if your address changes, you are not required to carry a certificate that shows your current address. The FAA will not issue a new certificate upon receipt of your new address unless you send a written request and $2 to the address shown above. (14 CFR 61.60)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: A certificated private pilot may not act as pilot in command of an aircraft towing a glider unless there is entered in the pilot's logbook a minimum of
answers: 100 hours of pilot flight time in any aircraft the pilot is using to tow a glider.
100 hours of pilot-in-command time in the aircraft category, class, and type, if required, that the pilot is using to tow a glider.
200 hours of pilot-in-command time in the aircraft category, class, and type, if required, that the pilot is using to tow a glider.
questions.explanation: As a private pilot, you may not act as pilot in command of an aircraft towing a glider unless you have had, and entered in your logbook, at least 100 hours of pilot-in-command time in the aircraft category, class, and type, if required, that you are using to tow a glider. (14 CFR 61.69)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft towing a glider, a pilot is required to have made within the preceding 24 months
answers: at least three flights as observer in a glider being towed by an aircraft.
at least three flights in a powered glider.
at least three actual or simulated glider tows while accompanied by a qualified pilot.
questions.explanation: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft towing a glider, you are required to have made, in the preceding 24 months, (1) At least three actual or simulated glider tows while accompanied by a qualified pilot or (2) At least three flights as pilot in command of a glider towed by an aircraft. (14 CFR 61.69)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If you are operating under BasicMed, you may fly an aircraft with
answers: an actual takeoff weight of no more than 12,500 lb.
a maximum certificated takeoff weight of no more than 12,500 lb.
any weight, as long as you do not exceed the aircraft's maximum certificated takeoff weight.
questions.explanation: If you are operating under BasicMed, you may fly an aircraft with a maximum certificated takeoff weight of no more than 12,500 lb. 14 CFR Part 1 defines aircraft that weigh 12,500 lb. or less as small aircraft. (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: In regard to privileges and limitations, a private pilot may
answers: act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying a passenger for compensation if the flight is in connection with a business or employment.
not pay less than the pro rata share of the operating expenses of a flight with passengers provided the expenses involve only fuel, oil, airport expenditures, or rental fees.
not be paid in any manner for the operating expenses of a flight.
questions.explanation: A private pilot may not pay less than an equal (pro rata) share of the operating expenses of a flight with passengers. These expenses may involve only fuel, oil, airport expenditures (e.g., landing fees, tie-down fees, etc.), or rental fees. (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: According to regulations pertaining to privileges and limitations, a private pilot may
answers: be paid for the operating expenses of a flight if at least three takeoffs and three landings were made by the pilot within the preceding 90 days.
not pay less than the pro rata share of the operating expenses of a flight with passengers provided the expenses involve only fuel, oil, airport expenditures, or rental fees.
not be paid in any manner for the operating expenses of a flight.
questions.explanation: A private pilot may not pay less than an equal (pro rata) share of the operating expenses of a flight with passengers. These expenses may involve only fuel, oil, airport expenditures (e.g., landing fees, tie-down fees, etc.), or rental fees. (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: What exception, if any, permits a private pilot to act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers who pay for the flight?
answers: If the passengers pay all the operating expenses.
If a donation is made to a charitable organization for the flight.
There is no exception.
questions.explanation: A private pilot may act as pilot in command of an airplane used in a passenger-carrying airlift sponsored by a charitable organization for which passengers make donations to the organization, provided the following requirements are met: the responsible Flight Standards office is notified at least 7 days before the flight, the flight is conducted from an adequate public airport, the pilot has logged at least 500 hr., no aerobatic or formation flights are performed, the 100-hr. inspection of the airplane requirement is complied with, and the flight is day-VFR. (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: If you are operating under BasicMed, what is the maximum speed at which you may fly?
answers: 250 KIAS.
250 KIAS below 10,000 feet, and 230 KIAS above 10,000 feet.
200 KIAS below 10,000 feet, and 230 KIAS above 10,000 feet.
questions.explanation: If you are operating under BasicMed, you may fly an aircraft at a maximum speed of 250 KIAS. (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: You own an aircraft that is certificated to carry 8 occupants and has a total of 8 seats installed, including the pilot's seat. You have recently elected to fly under BasicMed. May you continue to fly the aircraft?
answers: Yes, if you remove 2 of the seats.
Yes, as long as you carry no more than 6 passengers.
No.
questions.explanation: If you are operating under BasicMed, you may only fly aircraft that are authorized under federal law to carry no more than 7 occupants. Aircraft may only be operated under BasicMed pursuant to their type certificate data sheet (TCDS) or supplemental type certificate (STC). (14 CFR 61.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 61: Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

questions.question: The final authority as to the operation of an aircraft is the
answers: Federal Aviation Administration.
pilot in command.
aircraft manufacturer.
questions.explanation: The final authority as to the operation of an aircraft is the pilot in command. (14 CFR 91.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When must a pilot who deviates from a regulation during an emergency send a written report of that deviation to the Administrator?
answers: Within 7 days.
Within 10 days.
Upon request.
questions.explanation: A pilot who deviates from a regulation during an emergency must send a written report of that deviation to the Administrator of the FAA only upon request. (14 CFR 91.3)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Who is responsible for determining if an aircraft is in condition for safe flight?
answers: A certificated aircraft mechanic.
The pilot in command.
The owner or operator.
questions.explanation: The pilot in command of an aircraft is directly responsible for, and is the final authority for, determining whether the airplane is in condition for safe flight. (14 CFR 91.7)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: You are PIC of a flight. During your preflight, you notice a mechanical discrepancy that you think makes the aircraft unairworthy. Who is responsible for this determination?
answers: A certificated aircraft mechanic.
The pilot-in-command.
The owner or operator.
questions.explanation: The pilot in command is responsible for ensuring the aircraft is in an airworthy condition before each flight. (14 CFR 91.7)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Where may an aircraft's operating limitations be found?
answers: On the airworthiness certificate.
In the current, FAA-approved flight manual, approved manual material, markings, and placards, or any combination thereof.
In the aircraft airframe and engine logbooks.
questions.explanation: An aircraft's operating limitations may be found in the current, FAA-approved flight manual, approved manual material, markings, and placards, or any combination thereof. (14 CFR 91.9)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Where may an aircraft's operating limitations be found if the aircraft has an Experimental or Special light-sport airworthiness certificate?
answers: Attached to the Airworthiness Certificate.
In the current, FAA-approved flight manual.
In the aircraft airframe and engine logbooks.
questions.explanation: The operating limitations for experimental aircraft and aircraft issued a special light-sport airworthiness certificate are a permanent part of the aircraft's airworthiness certificate and must remain in the aircraft during operation. (14 CFR 91.9 and AC 65-32A)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Under what conditions may objects be dropped from an aircraft?
answers: Only in an emergency.
If precautions are taken to avoid injury or damage to persons or property on the surface.
If prior permission is received from the Federal Aviation Administration.
questions.explanation: No pilot in command of a civil aircraft may allow any object to be dropped from that aircraft in flight that creates a hazard to persons or property. However, this section does not prohibit the dropping of any object if reasonable precautions are taken to avoid injury or damage to persons or property. (14 CFR 91.15)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: No person may attempt to act as a crewmember of a civil aircraft with
answers: .008 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.
.004 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.
.04 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.
questions.explanation: No person may act or attempt to act as a crewmember of a civil aircraft while having a .04% by weight or more alcohol in the blood. (14 CFR 91.17)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Under what condition, if any, may a pilot allow a person who is obviously under the influence of drugs to be carried aboard an aircraft?
answers: In an emergency or if the person is a medical patient under proper care.
Only if the person does not have access to the flight deck or pilot's compartment.
Under no condition.
questions.explanation: No pilot of a civil aircraft may allow a person who demonstrates by manner or physical indications that the individual is under the influence of drugs to be carried in that aircraft, except in an emergency or if the person is a medical patient under proper care. (14 CFR 91.17)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: You attended a party last night, and you consumed several glasses of wine. You are planning to fly your aircraft home and have been careful to make sure 8 hours have passed since your last alcoholic drink. You can make the flight now only if you are not under the influence of alcohol and your blood alcohol level is
answers: below .04%.
below .08%.
questions.explanation: 14 CFR Part 91 requires that the blood alcohol level be less than .04% and that 8 hr. pass between drinking alcohol and piloting an aircraft. A pilot with a blood alcohol level of .04% or greater after 8 hr. cannot fly until the blood alcohol falls below that amount. Even though blood alcohol may be well below .04%, a pilot cannot fly sooner than 8 hr. after drinking alcohol. (14 CFR 91.17)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: A person may not act as a crewmember of a civil aircraft if alcoholic beverages have been consumed by that person within the preceding
answers: 8 hours.
12 hours.
24 hours.
questions.explanation: No person may act as a crewmember of a civil aircraft if alcoholic beverages have been consumed by that person within the preceding 8 hours. (14 CFR 91.17)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: While experiencing a hangover, a pilot
answers: will have impaired motor and mental responses.
is no longer under the influence of alcohol.
may experience discomfort, but no impairment.
questions.explanation: While experiencing a hangover, a pilot is still under the influence of alcohol. Although a pilot may think they are functioning normally, motor and mental response impairment is still present. (14 CFR 91.17, FAA-H-8083-25B Chap 17)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Preflight action, as required for all flights away from the vicinity of an airport, shall include
answers: the designation of an alternate airport.
a study of arrival procedures at airports/heliports of intended use.
an alternate course of action if the flight cannot be completed as planned.
questions.explanation: Preflight actions for flights not in the vicinity of an airport include checking weather reports and forecasts, fuel requirements, alternatives available if the planned flight cannot be completed, and any known traffic delays. (14 CFR 91.103)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: In addition to other preflight actions for a VFR flight away from the vicinity of the departure airport, regulations specifically require the pilot in command to
answers: review traffic control light signal procedures.
check the accuracy of the navigation equipment and the emergency locator transmitter (ELT).
determine runway lengths at airports of intended use and the aircraft's takeoff and landing distance data.
questions.explanation: Preflight actions for a VFR flight away from the vicinity of the departure airport specifically require the pilot in command to determine runway lengths at airports of intended use and the aircraft's takeoff and landing distance data. (14 CFR 91.103)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Which preflight action is specifically required of the pilot prior to each flight?
answers: Check the aircraft logbooks for appropriate entries.
Become familiar with all available information concerning the flight.
Review wake turbulence avoidance procedures.
questions.explanation: Each pilot in command will, before beginning a flight, become familiar with all available information concerning that flight. (14 CFR 91.103)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: You are pilot-in-command of a VFR flight that you think will be within the fuel range of your aircraft. As part of your preflight planning you must
answers: be familiar with all instrument approaches at the destination airport.
list an alternate airport on the flight plan, and confirm adequate takeoff and landing performance at the destination airport.
obtain weather reports, forecasts, and fuel requirements for the flight.
questions.explanation: A required preflight action by the pilot in command of a flight not in the vicinity of an airport or a flight under IFR is to become familiar with all available information concerning that flight, including weather reports, forecasts, and fuel requirements. Additional preflight information for the flight includes alternatives available, runway length at airports of intended use, and takeoff and landing distance information. (14 CFR 91.103)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Flight crewmembers are required to keep their safety belts and shoulder harnesses fastened during
answers: takeoffs and landings.
all flight conditions.
flight in turbulent air.
questions.explanation: During takeoff and landing and while en route, each required flight crewmember shall keep his or her safety belt fastened while at the crewmember station. If shoulder harnesses are available, they must be used by crewmembers during takeoff and landing. (14 CFR 91.105)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Which best describes the flight conditions under which flight crewmembers are specifically required to keep their safety belts and shoulder harnesses fastened?
answers: Safety belts during takeoff and landing; shoulder harnesses during takeoff and landing.
Safety belts during takeoff and landing; shoulder harnesses during takeoff and landing and while en route.
Safety belts during takeoff and landing and while en route; shoulder harnesses during takeoff and landing.
questions.explanation: During takeoff and landing and while en route, each required flight crewmember shall keep his or her safety belt fastened while at the crewmember station. If shoulder harnesses are available, they must be used by crewmembers during takeoff and landing. (14 CFR 91.105)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: With respect to passengers, what obligation, if any, does a pilot in command have concerning the use of safety belts?
answers: The pilot in command must instruct the passengers to keep their safety belts fastened for the entire flight.
The pilot in command must brief the passengers on the use of safety belts and notify them to fasten their safety belts during taxi, takeoff, and landing.
The pilot in command has no obligation in regard to passengers' use of safety belts.
questions.explanation: The pilot in command is required to brief the passengers on the use of safety belts and notify them to fasten their safety belts during taxi, takeoff, and landing. (14 CFR 91.107)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: With certain exceptions, safety belts are required to be secured about passengers during
answers: taxi, takeoffs, and landings.
all flight conditions.
flight in turbulent air.
questions.explanation: During the taxi, takeoff, and landing of U.S.-registered civil aircraft, each person on board that aircraft must occupy a seat or berth with a safety belt and shoulder harness, if installed, properly secured about their person. However, a person who has not reached his or her second birthday may be held by an adult who is occupying a seat or berth, and a person on board for the purpose of engaging in sport parachuting may use the floor of the aircraft as a seat (but is still required to use approved safety belts for takeoff). (14 CFR 91.107)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Safety belts are required to be properly secured about which persons in an aircraft and when?
answers: Pilots only, during takeoffs and landings.
Passengers, during taxi, takeoffs, and landings only.
Each person on board the aircraft during the entire flight.
questions.explanation: Regulations require that safety belts in an airplane be properly secured about all passengers during taxi, takeoffs, and landings. (14 CFR 91.107)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: You are planning a trip and one of your passengers states that he prefers not to use his shoulder harness because it is uncomfortable. You should
answers: explain that it is a mandatory requirement and that he must use the shoulder harness during takeoff and landing.
allow him to use his seat belt for the entire trip without the shoulder harness.
allow him to use his seat belt for takeoff and landing and the shoulder harness while en route.
questions.explanation: Each person on board a U.S.-registered civil aircraft must occupy an approved seat with a safety belt and, if installed, a shoulder harness, properly secured during movement on the surface, takeoff, and landing. (14 CFR 91.107)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: No person may operate an aircraft in formation flight
answers: over a densely populated area.
in Class D airspace under special VFR.
except by prior arrangement with the pilot in command of each aircraft.
questions.explanation: No person may operate in formation flight except by arrangement with the pilot in command of each aircraft in formation. (14 CFR 91.111)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: An airplane and an airship are converging. If the airship is left of the airplane's position, which aircraft has the right-of-way?
answers: The airship.
The airplane.
Each pilot should alter course to the right.
questions.explanation: When aircraft of different categories are converging, the less maneuverable aircraft has the right-of-way. Thus, the airship has the right-of-way in this question. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When two or more aircraft are approaching an airport for the purpose of landing, the right-of-way belongs to the aircraft
answers: that has the other to its right.
that is the least maneuverable.
at the lower altitude, but it shall not take advantage of this rule to cut in front of or to overtake another.
questions.explanation: When two or more aircraft are approaching an airport for the purpose of landing, the aircraft at the lower altitude has the right-of-way, but it shall not take advantage of this rule to cut in front of or overtake another aircraft. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Which aircraft has the right-of-way over the other aircraft listed?
answers: Glider.
Airship.
Aircraft refueling other aircraft.
questions.explanation: If aircraft of different categories are converging, the right-of-way depends upon who has the least maneuverability. A glider has right-of-way over an airship, airplane, or rotorcraft. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Which aircraft has the right-of-way over all other air traffic?
answers: A balloon.
An aircraft in distress.
An aircraft on final approach to land.
questions.explanation: An aircraft in distress has the right-of-way over all other aircraft. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: What action should the pilots of a glider and an airplane take if on a head-on collision course?
answers: The airplane pilot should give way to the left.
The glider pilot should give way to the right.
Both pilots should give way to the right.
questions.explanation: When aircraft are approaching head-on, or nearly so (regardless of category), each aircraft shall alter course to the right. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: What action is required when two aircraft of the same category converge, but not head-on?
answers: The faster aircraft shall give way.
The aircraft on the left shall give way.
Each aircraft shall give way to the right.
questions.explanation: When two aircraft of the same category converge (but not head-on), the aircraft to the other's right has the right-of-way. Thus, an airplane on the left gives way to the airplane on the right. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Which aircraft has the right-of-way over the other aircraft listed?
answers: Airship.
Aircraft towing other aircraft.
Gyroplane.
questions.explanation: An aircraft towing or refueling another aircraft has the right-of-way over all engine-driven aircraft. An airship is an engine-driven, lighter-than-air aircraft that can be steered. (14 CFR 91.113)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: A seaplane and a motorboat are on crossing courses. If the motorboat is to the left of the seaplane, which has the right-of-way?
answers: The motorboat.
The seaplane.
Both should alter course to the right.
questions.explanation: When aircraft, or an aircraft and a vessel (e.g., a motorboat), are on crossing courses, the aircraft or vessel to the other's right has the right-of-way. Because the seaplane is to the motorboat's right, the seaplane has the right-of-way. (14 CFR 91.115)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When flying in a VFR corridor designated through Class B airspace, the maximum speed authorized is
answers: 180 knots.
200 knots.
250 knots.
questions.explanation: No person may operate an airplane in a VFR corridor designated through Class B airspace at an indicated airspeed of more than 200 knots (230 MPH). (14 CFR 91.117)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Unless otherwise authorized, what is the maximum indicated airspeed at which a person may operate an aircraft below 10,000 feet MSL?
answers: 200 knots.
250 knots.
288 knots.
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise authorized by ATC, no person may operate an aircraft below 10,000 feet MSL at an indicated airspeed of more than 250 knots (288 MPH). (14 CFR 91.117)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When flying in the airspace underlying Class B airspace, the maximum speed authorized is
answers: 200 knots.
230 knots.
250 knots.
questions.explanation: No person may operate an airplane in the airspace underlying Class B airspace at an indicated airspeed of more than 200 knots (230 MPH). (14 CFR 91.117)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Unless otherwise authorized, the maximum indicated airspeed at which aircraft may be flown when at or below 2,500 feet AGL and within 4 nautical miles of the primary airport of Class C airspace is
answers: 200 knots.
230 knots.
250 knots.
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise authorized, the maximum indicated airspeed at which an airplane may be flown when at or below 2,500 feet AGL and within 4 nautical miles of the primary airport of Class C airspace is 200 knots (230 MPH). (14 CFR 91.117)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, what is the minimum safe altitude for a pilot to operate an aircraft anywhere?
answers: An altitude allowing, if a power unit fails, an emergency landing without undue hazard to persons or property on the surface.
An altitude of 500 feet above the surface and no closer than 500 feet to any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure.
An altitude of 500 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 1,000 feet.
questions.explanation: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, an aircraft should always be operated at an altitude high enough to permit an emergency landing without endangering people or property on the ground. (14 CFR 91.119)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, what is the minimum safe altitude required for a pilot to operate an aircraft over congested areas?
answers: An altitude of 1,000 feet above any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure.
An altitude of 500 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 1,000 feet of the aircraft.
An altitude of 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 2,000 feet of the aircraft.
questions.explanation: When operating an aircraft over any congested area of a city, town, or settlement, or over an open-air assembly of persons, a pilot must remain at an altitude of 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 2,000 feet of the aircraft. (14 CFR 91.119)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, an aircraft may not be operated closer than what distance from any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure?
answers: 500 feet.
700 feet.
1,000 feet.
questions.explanation: Over uncongested areas, an altitude of 500 ft. above the surface is required. Over open water and sparsely populated areas, a distance of 500 ft. from any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure must be maintained. (14 CFR 91.119)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, what is the minimum safe altitude required for a pilot to operate an aircraft over other than a congested area?
answers: An altitude allowing, if a power unit fails, an emergency landing without undue hazard to persons or property on the surface.
An altitude of 500 feet AGL, except over open water or a sparsely populated area, which requires 500 feet from any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure.
An altitude of 500 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 1,000 feet.
questions.explanation: Over uncongested areas, an altitude of 500 ft. above the surface is required. Over open water and sparsely populated areas, a distance of 500 ft. from any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure must be maintained. (14 CFR 91.119)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: According to 14 CFR part 91, at what minimum altitude may an airplane be operated unless necessary for takeoff and landing?
answers: In congested areas, you must maintain 500 feet over obstacles, and no closer than 500 feet to any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure.
In uncongested areas, 1,000 feet over any obstacle within a horizontal radius of 2,000 feet.
An altitude allowing for an emergency landing without undue hazard, if a power unit fails.
questions.explanation: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, an aircraft should always be operated at an altitude high enough to permit an emergency landing without endangering people or property on the ground. (14 CFR 91.119)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: Prior to takeoff, the altimeter should be set to which altitude or altimeter setting?
answers: The current local altimeter setting, if available, or the departure airport elevation.
The corrected density altitude of the departure airport.
The corrected pressure altitude for the departure airport.
questions.explanation: Prior to takeoff, the altimeter should be set to either the local altimeter setting or to the departure airport elevation. (14 CFR 91.121)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: If an altimeter setting is not available before flight, to which altitude should the pilot adjust the altimeter?
answers: The elevation of the nearest airport corrected to mean sea level.
The elevation of the departure area.
Pressure altitude corrected for nonstandard temperature.
questions.explanation: When the local altimeter setting is not available at takeoff, the pilot should adjust the altimeter to the elevation of the departure area. (14 CFR 91.121)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: At what altitude shall the altimeter be set to 29.92 when climbing to cruising flight level?
answers: 14,500 feet MSL.
18,000 feet MSL.
24,000 feet MSL.
questions.explanation: Pressure altitude is the altitude used for all flights at and above 18,000 feet MSL, i.e., in Class A airspace. When climbing to or above 18,000 feet MSL, one does not use local altimeter settings, but rather 29.92" Hg after reaching 18,000 feet MSL. (14 CFR 91.121)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When would a pilot be required to submit a detailed report of an emergency which caused the pilot to deviate from an ATC clearance?
answers: Within 48 hours if requested by ATC.
Immediately.
Within 7 days.
questions.explanation: Each pilot in command who is given priority by ATC in an emergency shall, if requested by ATC, submit a detailed report within 48 hours to the manager of that ATC facility. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: If an in-flight emergency requires immediate action, the pilot in command may
answers: deviate from any rule of 14 CFR part 91 to the extent required to meet the emergency, but must submit a written report to the Administrator within 24 hours.
deviate from any rule of 14 CFR part 91 to the extent required to meet that emergency.
not deviate from any rule of 14 CFR part 91 unless prior to the deviation approval is granted by the Administrator.
questions.explanation: In an in-flight emergency requiring immediate action, the pilot in command may deviate from any rule of 14 CFR Part 91 to the extent required to meet that emergency. A written report of the deviation must be sent to the Administrator of the FAA only if requested. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: As Pilot in Command of an aircraft, under which situation can you deviate from an ATC clearance?
answers: When operating in Class A airspace at night.
If an ATC clearance is not understood and in VFR conditions.
In response to a traffic alert and collision avoidance system resolution advisory.
questions.explanation: No pilot may deviate from an ATC clearance unless an amended clearance is obtained, an emergency exists, or the deviation is in response to a traffic alert and collision avoidance system resolution advisory. A written report of the deviation must be sent to the Administrator of the FAA only if requested. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: When an ATC clearance has been obtained, no pilot in command may deviate from that clearance unless that pilot obtains an amended clearance. The one exception to this regulation is
answers: when the clearance states, "at pilot's discretion."
an emergency.
if the clearance contains a restriction.
questions.explanation: When an ATC clearance has been obtained, no pilot in command may deviate from that clearance, except in an emergency, unless an amended clearance is obtained. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: What action, if any, is appropriate if the pilot deviates from an ATC instruction during an emergency and is given priority?
answers: Take no special action because you are pilot in command.
File a detailed report within 48 hours to the manager of the appropriate ATC facility, if requested.
File a report to the FAA Administrator, as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: Each pilot in command who is given priority by ATC in an emergency shall, if requested by ATC, submit a detailed report within 48 hours to the manager of that ATC facility. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: As pilot-in-command of an aircraft, you may deviate from an ATC clearance when
answers: flying in the outer ring of Class C airspace.
operating under VFR in Class B airspace.
there is an in-flight emergency requiring immediate action.
questions.explanation: A pilot may deviate from ATC clearance or instruction only in the case of an in-flight emergency requiring immediate action. In such a case, the pilot should notify ATC of the deviation as soon as possible. (14 CFR 91.123)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: What is the specific fuel requirement for flight under VFR at night in an airplane?
answers: Enough to complete the flight at normal cruising speed with adverse wind conditions.
Enough to fly to the first point of intended landing and to fly after that for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.
Enough to fly to the first point of intended landing and to fly after that for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
questions.explanation: The night VFR requirement is enough fuel to fly to the first point of intended landing and to fly thereafter for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed given forecast conditions. (14 CFR 91.151)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151

questions.question: What is the specific fuel requirement for flight under VFR during daylight hours in an airplane?
answers: Enough to complete the flight at normal cruising speed with adverse wind conditions.
Enough to fly to the first point of intended landing and to fly after that for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.
Enough to fly to the first point of intended landing and to fly after that for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
questions.explanation: The day-VFR requirement is enough fuel to fly to the first point of intended landing and thereafter for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed. (14 CFR 91.151)
questions.subcategory: 14 CFR Part 91: General Operating and Flight Rules -- 91.3-91.151
